edu.gvsu.dlunit

Class BitSetUtilities

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.gvsu.dlunit.BitSetUtilities

  • public class BitSetUtilities
extends java.lang.Object
    Methods used to convert between BitSets and other data types.

    Important note about creating BitSets representing negative numbers: Traditionally, the most significant bit of a set of bits is the sign bit. However, in the current implementation of java.util.BitSet, the user cannot specify precisely how many bits are represented: As with an ArrayList, the times at which the capacity grows is not strictly specified. Therefore, myBitSet.get(myBitSet.size() -1) is not guaranteed to be the sign bit. The user is responsible for remembering the location of the sign bit in any given BitSet.

    Author:
    Zachary Kurmas, David Poplowski

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  BitSetUtilities.InvalidWidthException
      Thrown when a user specifies that a BitSet has a width that is clearly wrong (for example, the BitSet 11111 is clearly not 4 bits wide), or tries to create a BitSet that is too narrow for the intended data (for example, tries to create a 4 bit BitSet containing the number 1203).
      static class  BitSetUtilities.WidthTooSmallException
      Exception thrown when user requests that a large value be represented using too few bits (e.g., that 1024 be represented using 5 bits).

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static int SMALL_AS_POSSIBLE
      Used to specify that a BitSet should be as small as possible given the data to be placed into it.

    • Field Detail

      • SMALL_AS_POSSIBLE

        public static final int SMALL_AS_POSSIBLE
        Used to specify that a BitSet should be as small as possible given the data to be placed into it. (For example, that 5 should use 3 bits only.)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • equals

        public static boolean equals(java.util.BitSet a,
                             java.util.BitSet b,
                             int width)
        Compare two BitSets for equality up to the specified width.
        Parameters:
        a - a BitSet to compare
        b - a BitSet to compare
        width - the number of bits to compare.
        Returns:
        true if the lowest width bits of the two bit sets are equals. Also, by definition, null == null; however, the comparison between a null and non-null objects will always be false, even if width == 0.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if width < 0.

      • create

        public static java.util.BitSet create(java.math.BigInteger value,
                                      boolean signed,
                                      int desired_width)
        Create a BitSet from a BigInteger. See note about about creating BitSets representing negative numbers.
        Parameters:
        value - The BigInteger to convert to a BitSet.
        signed - true if the BitSet should represent a signed integer.
        desired_width - The desired width of the BitSet. This has little effect when creating an unsigned BitSet. For a signed BitSet, it specifies the location of the sign bit. A value of SMALL_AS_POSSIBLE will put the sign bit in the lowest position possible given value.
        Returns:
        The corresponding BitSet. If the input is null the output will be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if signed is true and value is negative.
        BitSetUtilities.WidthTooSmallException - if desired_width is too small.

        public static java.util.BitSet create(java.math.BigInteger value,
                                      boolean signed)
        Identical to create(BigInteger, boolean, int) with a desired_width of SMALL_AS_POSSIBLE.
        Parameters:
        value - the BigInteger to convert to a BitSet
        signed - true if the BitSet should represent a signed integer.
        Returns:
        The corresponding BitSet.

      • create

        public static java.util.BitSet create(java.lang.String value,
                                      boolean signed,
                                      int desired_width)
        Create a bitset from a String containing an integer. The String is assumed to be in base-10, unless it begins with "0x" or "0X". See note about about creating BitSets representing negative numbers.
        Parameters:
        value - The String.
        signed - true if the BitSet should represent a signed integer.
        desired_width - The desired width of the BitSet. This has little effect when creating an unsigned BitSet. For a signed BitSet, it specifies the location of the sign bit. A value of SMALL_AS_POSSIBLE will put the sign bit in the lowest possition possible given value.
        Returns:
        The corresponding BitSet.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if signed is true andvalue is negative.
        BitSetUtilities.WidthTooSmallException - if desired_width is too small.
        java.lang.NumberFormatException - if value does not contain an integer.

      • UnsignedBitSetToString

        public static java.lang.String UnsignedBitSetToString(java.util.BitSet bs,
                                                      int radix)
        Convert a BitSet to a String representation in the specified radix. Written by Dave Poplowski
        Parameters:
        bs - The BitSet to convert.
        radix - The radix (i.e., base) used when converting the BitSet. See BigInteger.toString(int).
        Returns:
        A String representation of the BitSet in the specified radix.

      • SignedBitSetToString

        public static java.lang.String SignedBitSetToString(java.util.BitSet bs,
                                                    int radix,
                                                    int bits)
        Convert a BitSet in two's complement form to a String representation in the specified base. Partially written by DavePoplowski.
        Parameters:
        bs - The BitSet to convert.
        radix - The radix (i.e., base) used when converting the BitSet. See BigInteger.toString(int).
        bits - the width of the data --- in particular, width specifies the location of the sign bit. (See comment above for more details.)
        Returns:
        A String representation of the BitSet.
        Throws:
        BitSetUtilities.WidthTooSmallException - if the width of the BitSet is longer than the specified width and the bits more more significant width can not be reasonably interpreted to be an integer with the specified width. In particular, the bits more significatn than width must be either (1) All identical to width, or (2) some number of zeros followed by 1s. (In contrast, if the bits more significant than width are 100110111, then there is no reasonable interpretation and an exception is thrown.)

      • BitSetToString

        public static java.lang.String BitSetToString(java.util.BitSet bs,
                                              int radix,
                                              boolean signed,
                                              int width)
        Convert a BitSet in two's complement form to a String.

        Partially written by DavePoplowski.

        Parameters:
        bs - The BitSet to convert.
        radix - The radix (i.e., base) used when converting the BitSet. See BigInteger.toString(int).
        signed - true if bs represents a signed value, false otherwise.
        width - the width of the data. Specifying the width is necessary so that we know where the sign bit is. (See comment above for more details.)
        Returns:
        A String representation of the BitSet.
        Throws:
        BitSetUtilities.WidthTooSmallException - if a signed conversion is requested and the width of the BitSet is longer than width. (No exception is thrown when doing an unsigned conversion.)
